717001f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from Rector Street, showing Trinity
Church in the background.
1879.

717004f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north across Rector Street, showing prominently Trinity Church and 9hurchyard occupying the frontage from Rector to Thames Streets. Beyond is the Western
Union Building with clock tower atop.
About 1885
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717006f-a.text:
Broadway,between Rector ani Thames Street,East Side and at the head of Wall Street,showing Trinity Church,P.E. It
was granted a Royal Charter in I697.
Ref: King's Handbooi bo New York,I892
Pp 341-342
About I890
Detroit Photograph Co.
Copyright.

717026f-a.text:
Broadway, north from a point between
Wall and Pine Street'w and across the latter, showing nrominently the old Ecuitable Building occupying the 'ine to Cedar Street frontage. This structure erected in 1872, and enlarged in 1887, .contains the main offices of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of t e United SEates. To the right is the 5-story structure at the N.E. corner of Pine that was included in the site for the present 21-story American Surity Co. Building. The structure with a clock tower atop and on the far side of the Ecuitable Building is No.
134-46 Broadway.
This was the former home of the Yutual Life Insurance Uompany and subsequently occupied by the American Fire Insurance Co. Later the Guaranty Trust Company built there. For a sirilar iliustration-see King's Handbook of New York 1893page 671.
About 1890
:ift of Urbrohk Collection

716996f-a.text:
Broadway, st the S. W. corner of Rector Street. Shown is the building in which the financier Russell Sage was the object of a bomb explosion that injured an innocent bystander. This structure was replaced in 1897 by the 21 story Empire Building. On the right is a view westward on Rector Street to Trinity Place. The Rector Street station of the Sixth Avenue Elevated Line appears there. At the margin is a portion of Trinity Churchyard.
About 1895
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717007f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, at Wall Street, showing a complete view of Trinity Church. Also shown is a general view of the lower west side of Manhattan, with the Hudson River and lower Bay clearly shown. Note the Statue of
Liberty dimly discernible on the right.
About 1895.
Eugene L. Armbruster Colkh ction.

717008f-a.text:
Trinity Church,P.E. located on Broadway,between Rector and Thames Streets,at the hesd of Wall Street.
Copyright in I539 by,
A.Loeffler.

723834f-a.text:
Wall Street, east from Broadway. The trolley
tracks are on Broadway.
M.B.R.  1890-1900.
NEG #3215

716992f.text:
Broadway, west side, south from Rector Street.
May 28, 1904
Brown Bros.

717009f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, from and including Wall Street, to, but not including Exchange Place. No. 1 Wall Street, at the S.E. corner of
Broadway, is at the left of Trinity Church.
About 1905.
Irving Underhill.

716994f-a.text:
73-69 Broadway, at the S.W. corner of Rector Street, showing the 21-story Empire Building. The street on the right is Rector Street, of which this structure forms the south side while Trinity Grave Yard forms the other. On Trinity Place is a station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line.
About 1915.
Gift of E.M. Jenks.
Underhill.

717028f.text:
90-94, 96 and 100 Broadway, east side, north from Wall (right) to Pine (left) Streets, showing 3 structures occupying this entire block front. They are respectively, the First National Bank, the Schermerhorn
and the American Surity [sic, Surety] Buildings.
About 1915.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

716991f-a.text:
73 to 51 Broadway (left), west side, south from and including Rector Street, to a point slightly south of Exchange Alley, showing the 21-story Empire Building (Nos. 73-69), the 21-story American Railway Express Co. Building (Nos. 65-63), and the lower floors of the 32-story Adams Building (Nos. 61-57). Also shown (right) is Rector Street, south side, west from Broadway, to Trinity Place, showing that side of the Empire Building.
August 7, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

716995f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, at Wall Street, showing the lower stories of four buildings at the S.E. corner that is the site of the present 50-story Irving Trust Co. Building. No. 86-84 is an 18-story structure at the corner. adjacent to same is an 11-story building, No. 82. Successively in order are the 11-story Central Union Trust Co. at No. 80 and the 21-story Century Building No. 74-72.
About 1928.
Herbert Photos Incorporated.

716999f-b.text:
(1)
Broadway (foreground), at the S.E. corner of Wall Street (left) showing the structures at that location where the huge Irving Trust Company Bldg. will rise. Note to the left of same, the spire of Trinity Church. In the background, prominently seen is the 38 storied Equitable Trust Co. Bldg. The photographer is viewing eastward across the graveyard of the Church, from No. 74 Trinity Place.
May 13, 1929
P. L. Sperr,
(2)
A view from the same vantage point after the aforementioned demolition. Across same appears the rear of the New York Stock Exchange
Building.
Aug. 20, 1929
P. L. Srerr,

716999f-a.text:
(1)
Broadway (foreground), at the S.E. corner of Wall Street (left) showing the structures at that location where the huge Irving Trust Company Bldg. will rise. Note to the left of same, the spire of Trinity Church. In the background, prominently seen is the 38 storied Equitable Trust Co. Bldg. The photographer is viewing eastward across the graveyard of the Church, from No. 74 Trinity Place.
May 13, 1929
P. L. Sperr,
(2)
A view from the same vantage point after the aforementioned demolition. Across same appears the rear of the New York Stock Exchange
Building.
Aug. 20, 1929
P. L. Srerr,

717000f-a.text:
(1)
Broadway, east side, at Wall Street, showing under demolition Nos. 86-84, 82 and 80 Broadway, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Wall Street. These in conjunction with adjoining property formed the site of the present (1937) 50-story Irving Trust Building, known as No. 1 Wall Street. This view is photographed in an eastward direction on Rector Street and shows on the left, the southern edge of Trinity Cemetery, across which appears the 11-story First National Bank, No. 90-94 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of Wall Street. This was demolished and improved with a 21-story structure slightly later.
January 11, 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
A view solely of the future Irving Trust site as viewed southeastward from in front of Trinity Church (right).
January 11, 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(3)
The same as No. 1 at a later date and viewed southeastward. Demolition has been completed for the Irving Trust Co. Building and the steel frame work is rising. On the right appears a clearer view of the First National Bank, No. 90-94, as mentioned in No. 1.
August 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)

These in conjunction with adjoining property formed the site of the present (1937) 50-story Irving Trust Building, known as No. 1 Wall Street. This view is photographed in an eastward direction on Rector Street and shows on the left, the southern edge of Trinity Cemetery, across which appears the 11-story First National Bank, No. 90-94 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of Wall Street. P. L. Sperr.

717015f-b.text:
(1)
Broadway, west side, at the head of Wall Street, showing Trinity Church and Grave Yard that extends westward to Church Street. Excavation in the foreground is for the new 50-story Irving Trust Co.
Building, No. 1 Wall Street.
August 7, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a slightly different angle.
August 7, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

717024f-a.text:
(1)
Broadway, east side, north from Wall to Pine Streets,
August 7, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, in an eastward direction, as seen from No. 74 Trinity Place. The buildings occupying this block front are, the 21-story American Surety Co. Building, No. 100-96 Broadway, at the S.E. corner of Pine Street and the 11-story First National Bank, 94-90 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of Wall Street. The latter was replaced by a 21-story structure in 1931.
NEG # 3325  August 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

717024f-b.text:
(1)
Broadway, east side, north from Wall to Pine Streets,
August 7, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, in an eastward direction, as seen from No. 74 Trinity Place. The buildings occupying this block front are, the 21-story American Surety Co. Building, No. 100-96 Broadway, at the S.E. corner of Pine Street and the 11-story First National Bank, 94-90 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of Wall Street. The latter was replaced by a 21-story structure in 1931.
NEG # 3325  August 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

723833f-a.text:
Nos. 2-6 Wall Street, at the N.E. corner of
Broadway as viewed across the Irving Trust Co. Building site. This structure, erected in 1880, is occupied by the First National Bank, tho constructed for the National Bank of the Republic, when it was better known as "Fort Sherman." For details see King's Handbook of New York
1893, page 724.
The photographer gives his vantage points as the Stock Exchange (No. 1) and the Empire Building (No. 2). Note in the former the partial glimpse of Trinity Cemetery on the opposite side of Broadway.
August 7, 1929
Views 1, 2
P. L. Sperr

723833f-b.text:
Nos. 2-6 Wall Street, at the N.E. corner of
Broadway as viewed across the Irving Trust Co. Building site. This structure, erected in 1880, is occupied by the First National Bank, tho constructed for the National Bank of the Republic, when it was better known as "Fort Sherman." For details see King's Handbook of New York
1893, page 724.
The photographer gives his vantage points as the Stock Exchange (No. 1) and the Empire Building (No. 2). Note in the former the partial glimpse of Trinity Cemetery on the opposite side of Broadway.
August 7, 1929
Views 1, 2
P. L. Sperr

723837f-a.text:
Wall Street, south side, east from Broadway, to and including
New Street,
Early 1929.

723825f-a.text:
No. 1 Wall Street, at the S.E. corner of Broadway, as seen from the Church street side of Trinity Church Grave Yard, looking eastward.
Building shown is the Irving Trust Company.
About 1930.
Ewing Galloway.

717016f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, at the head of Wall Street, showing Trinity Church
and Graveyard extending westward to Trinity Place.
About 1931
Wurts Bros.

717020f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, at Wall Street, as seen across Trinity Church yard and from the N.Y. Curb Exchange Building, showing prominently the 50-story Irving Trust Building, at the S.E. corner of Wall Street and Broadway. Opposite same (left) is the 21-story structure of the First
National Bank.
November 25, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

717017f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, at the head of Wall Street. This view of Trinity Church and grouhds was photographed southeastward, from a point near Trinity Place and silhouettes the church steeple againstAo.50-story Irving Trust Co. Building, at the S.E. corner of Broadway at Wall Street. Shown on the right, are the upper stories of the Empire Building, a 22-story building forming the south side of Rector Street, between Trinity Place and Broadway.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

717010f.text:
Broadway, north from Wall Street, showing mainly the upper portions of structures that line the west side of the Street; prominently of which appear, the spires of Trinity Church and the Woolworth Building. No, 1 is an enlargement by the photographer; No. 2 being a copy of the
original negative by the N.Y.P.L.
About 1936.
Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A.R.P.S.

717018f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, at the head of Wall Street, showing a
portion of the tower of Trinity Church.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y.' by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

717023f-a.text:
86, 84, 80 and 76 Broadway (left to right) at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Wall Street, as seen from Trinity Church Yard and viewing eastward to show prominently the 11-story building, No. 80, occupied by the Union Trust Co. For a contempory view, see, Kings Handbook of New York (1892) page 709.
About 1890.
Brown Brothers.

717025f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from a point between Wall and Pine Streets and across the latter showing prominently the Equitable Building occupying the frontage from Pine to Cedar Streets. For a slightly earlier view of this area see Kings Handbook of New York of New York (1893) page 671, also Urbrock Collection - photo of 1890.
About 1900
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
NEG #2997

723826f-a.text:
No. 1 Wall Street, south side, east from Broadway to New Street, showing the 50-story Irving Trust Co. Building, which occupies this site. This is viewed southwestward through the clearance for the Bankers Trust
addition and shows the N.E. corner of building concerned.
July 26, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

723835f-b.text:
(1)
Wall Street, east from Trinity Church Yard, which is west
of Broadway.
December 1, 1931.
P.L. Sperr
(2)
The same, prior to the erection of the 50-story Irving Trust Co. Building shown in view 1. On the lower right of this view, the site is shown being prepared. On the opposite corner (shown under demolition in No. 1) is the 11-story First National Bank. Towering over this is the 39-story Bankers Trust Co. Building. The modern type structure in the right background is the 38-story Equitable Trust Co. Building.
August 20, 1929.
P.L. Sperr.

723835f-a.text:
(1)
Wall Street, east from Trinity Church Yard, which is west
of Broadway.
December 1, 1931.
P.L. Sperr
(2)
The same, prior to the erection of the 50-story Irving Trust Co. Building shown in view 1. On the lower right of this view, the site is shown being prepared. On the opposite corner (shown under demolition in No. 1) is the 11-story First National Bank. Towering over this is the 39-story Bankers Trust Co. Building. The modern type structure in the right background is the 38-story Equitable Trust Co. Building.
August 20, 1929.
P.L. Sperr.
